div.p: 1. IV:30. Sunday
Sun rose 5:24. Set 6:36. Day 13 hours 12 minutes.
Clear morn and Eve and I saw them both from Charles’s porch

Heard Mr Joseph Pearce Cranch, a younger Son, of my Cousin judge William Cranch of Washington. His morning text was from John 6.63. [“]It is the Spirit that quickeneth; the flesh profiteth nothing: the words that I speak unto you, they are Spirit and they are life.” The chapter containing this text is one of the most mysterious and solemn of the whole bible; especially from verse 48 to 71. the end of the chapter— This very 63d. verse is the solution of most if not of all the numberless difficulties, and monstrous absurdities which have been perverted some by one sect and some by another into creeds and articles of faith— The words that he speaks are Spirit and life— Their doctrine is immortality, their language is spiritual, figurative, metaphorical— Almost all the inconceivable blunders of Christians in reading the new Testament have sprung from giving a literal interpretation to figurative speech— In this Chapter Jesus says Except ye eat the flesh of the Son of man, and drink his blood, ye have no life in you— And this declaration did so shock his disciples, that from that time, many of them went back and walked no more with him— Yet on taking the passover, just before his crucifixion, he broke the bread, and gave it to his disciples, saying this is my body—and in giving the cup said This cup is the new testament in my blood, which is shed for you. A repetition of the same figure which he had used at Capernaum— But John’s gospel is the only that gives the discourse at Capernaum, and the only one that omits the institution of the paschal supper. It must be admitted that the positive command to the disciples to eat his flesh, and to drink his blood, was, without explanation exceedingly revolting, but the explanation at Capernaum, and especially that of the last supper ought to have satisfied them all— And how with the two explanations the doctrine of transubstantiation could ever arise is utterly inconceivable— A collection for the parish library was taken up after the morning service. Mr Cranch and Mr Lunt dined with us— The afternoon text was Job. 7.17. [“]What is man that thou shouldst magnify him? and that thou shouldest set thine heart upon him? 18 And that thou shouldest visit him every morning, and try him every moment?” The doctrine derived from this text was that the superior excellence of the nature of man was proved by the trials to which he has been subject by the Providence of God—an ingenious deduction, disclosing a meditative mind— I read the 6th. Sermon of Dr Parker’s volume. Scriptural definitions of the Christian character— The text, if any man be in Christ, he is a new Creature—and then the doctrine of regeneration.— Scarcely a skimming upon the surface of a deep abyss. Regeneration is another of the unfathomable depths of Christianity, sprung from the senseless practice of receiving in a literal sense that which was figuratively spoken— Mr Thomas Greenleaf was here towards Evening, and left with me, his report from the Committee on the Accounts of the Treasurer of the Temple and School fund Corporation, shewing a balance of 945 dollars and 52 cents now in his hands. Mr E. Price Greenleafis so far recovered that he was at Meeting this day, Morning and afternoon. Charles and his wife were here this Evening.
2. III:30 Monday
Hingham. Steamboat— Boston. Gilletts Stage— Quincy.

At five O’Clock this morning I took passage at French’s tavern, for Hingham, in the Plymouth Stage. There was one other passenger in it, from Boston, and a double barrell’d fowling piece. He took his seat on the outside, with the driver when I got in— On the way another passenger got in at Weymouth who was going to the centennial celebration to be held to-morrow at Barnstable— The Stage started from French’s about half past 5 and at a quarter past 6. I alighted at the Post Office in Hingham, immediately opposite Mr Loring’s house— I called on him, and found he was going to Boston in the Steamer General Lincoln, which was precisely my own purpose— Mr Loring took me in his chaise to the boat about half a mile from his house— She left the wharf precisely at 7. and at half past 8 landed at the wharf, at the end of Pearl street Boston— The harbour at Hingham is perfectly land locked, and the passage to Boston is through a succession of Islands all the way through— The Quincy stone-meeting House, and Charles’s house are in sight perhaps through half the passage, and the town of Hull lying between two hills is full in view— There were I think not less than one hundred passengers in the boat— Among them Mr Baker who was upon our last fishing party, Mr Jairus Lincoln, Mr William C Greenleaf, who had passed the Sunday at Hingham, where his bien aimée Mary Whitney is upon a visit to her friends— The boat went round Georges Island, in complaisance to me, and Mr Loring said the Captain, would receive no pay for my passage, which I suppose meant that he paid for it himself. He walked with me to Charles’s Office, and urged me much to return in the boat at 1. O’Clock, promising to take me home from Hingham. But I preferred returning directly to Quincy.— I soon called at 106 State Street to inquire for Mr Nathaniel Curtis, but he was not there. I waited for him at Charles’s Office where he afterwards came, and I read to him and gave him the draught of a petition which I had prepared for the children of the late Moses Gill, to the judge of Probate for the County of Worcester, praying him to grant Letters of Administration to Mr Fuller, on the Estates of Governor Gill, and of the late Moses Gill— Mr Fuller is to proceed tomorrow to Worcester— I called twice at the House of Mr Blagden, the Minister of the Old South Church, but neither time was he at home— I visited Mrs Dexter, who urged me to stay and dine with her, but I declined— Visited also Dr. Abner Phelps at 23. Oliver Street; where though it was just after one, I found Mrs Phelps and two other Ladies at dinner— The doctor was not with them, but came down from his chamber, and sent for his next door neighbour who came in; and we had half an hour of pleasant conversation. After a visit to the Silversmith shop—opposite the old State-house I went to Charles’s Office and read in the North American Review for last April, an Article upon Southey’s works, and several others, all dull, at 4. O’Clock I went to Elm-street and took passage in Gillett’s omnibus for Quincy— Met there Mr and Mrs DeWint with their infant child and a Nurse Harriet Welsh, Mr Thomas Greenleaf, Mr Lemuel Bracket, Mr Marsh and half a dozen women—Miss Welsh came to Charles’s house, and with him and his wife spent the eve here.
3. V:27. Tuesday
Sun rose 5:27. Set 6:33. Day 13 hours 6 minutes—

The Sun was risen before I was dressed. I saw him set from the porch of Charles’s house— Morning visit from Mr Joseph Angier of Milton, with his Cousin Mr Luther Angier a young Clergyman of New-York. In the conversation with them Mr Luther Angier mentioned judge James Lanman who was several years a member of the Senate of the United States, as having expressed to him a friendly feeling to me, a feeling which I told him was on my part altogether reciprocal. I said that just fifty years ago in the first week of September 1789. being a student at Law in the Office of Theophilus Parsons at Newbury-Port, and going on a visit to my father then Vice-President of the United States at New-York I met at Providence and went down to Newport, in one of the small packets which then plied between those places, a young man, whose name I found to be Peter Lanman— Thursday was beautiful but calm so that we could only drift down the river with the tide, and twice at the turn of the tide were obliged to cast anchor and lay six hours without moving forward an inch. We were all Night on the river and reached Newport about Sunrise. There I was detained two or three days by head winds before I could embark in the Packet for New-York— Mr Lanman after a shorter detention, perhaps only of one day, crossed the river and proceed to Norwich, which was his home. But upon this very short and casual acquaintance I found him so very pleasant, intelligent and amiable a companion that we were something like the two German young Ladies in the Poetry of the Anti-Jacobin who meet at a tavern and swear to each other eternal friendship— But from that day for more than thirty years I neither saw nor heard any thing of Peter Lanman— When James Lanman came to Washington, as a Senator from Connecticut, I enquired of him whether Peter Lanman was related to him and he told me he was his brother— He afterwards came repeatedly to Washington and was I think appointed by Mr Monroe in February 1824. Consul at Kingston in the Island of Jamaica. But the British Government at that time refused to admit Consuls from the United States at their Colonial Ports—and I had heard with much regret that Mr Peter Lanman had not been so successful in life as his brother— Mr Angier said it was so and that his brother had been to a considerable extent involved in his misfortunes— Mr Joseph Angier then said that his cousin was shortly to be married to a daughter of Mr James Lanman. Mr E. Price Greenleaf was here this afternoon and examined the Apple and Pear buds, which he had inserted on the 3d. and 10th. of August; all of which he thinks have taken. But the inoculation of the pignut hickories have all failed. The stoutest of my Philadelphia seedling white maples which on the first of June last was 7. inches in circumference at the ground is now nine inches; and the budded cherry then 37 inches high is now 54. and has stopped growing for the Season— The tallest of the five Apple seedlings at the seminary gate is 3 feet 4 inches high. the second—31 inches 3 stunted— A Seminary wild pear seedlinginches— Miss Welsh here this Evening.
4. IV: Wednesday—
Supervisors of Temple and School fund Meeting. Pic-Nic.

At Noon the Meeting of the Supervisors of the Temple, and School fund was held at my house. All the members present. The report of the Committee, Mr Greenleaf and myself upon the Treasurer’s account was read and accepted and a vote passed at my motion that the treasurer be directed to invest the funds in his hands, as soon as may be convenient in the manner prescribed, by the Deeds of grant; that is, in funds of the United States or of this Commonwealth— They are now in Notes from the town of Quincy— The lease of a house lot on the Hancock lot was received recorded. And another lease of a small strip of land, to Solomon Hayden by the last years Selectmen, but not executed by him, was presented for execution by the Surveyors— After much discussion, it appeared that by the terms of the Deeds the Select men of the Town alone can execute leases of the Lands, and that the Supervisors have only an advisory power— The lease was for 20 years and there was a proviso that if at the end of that time the parties could not agree upon a renewal, the buildings erected upon it by the lessee should be taken at an appraisement— Mr Miller objected to this and proposed that the right reserved by the lessee should only be to take off his buildings— Much debate— I offered a Resolution to that effect which was adopted and a Committee of Mr Miller and myself were appointed to notify the selectmen, and confer with them thereon— I agreed with Mr Miller to meet him at the Selectmen’s weekly meeting next Saturday afternoon— Mr Jewett was reappointed as the Agent of the Corporation, for taking care of the Lands; and a Committee was appointed to lay out a street from the Neponset Bridge road to the private road opened by me, over the hill— About half past two the Meeting was dissolved; and the members, with Charles and his wife, and Mrs. De Wint, and her daughter Julia dined with us— Mr De Wint was so much indisposed that he could not come— Harriet Welsh had returned this morning to Boston— The Pic Nic party of the Ladies of Quincy assembled at 3. P.M.— I had sent an excuse from Meeting them at that hour, owing to my previous engagement; but had promised to go in the Evening— Mr Quincy left us about 6. to return to Cambridge— I then walked with the other Gentlemen to the Green where the company were assembled— At our approach the Committee of 16 young maidens in uniform white muslin dresses, with Straw Sheperdess hats, and a green wreath around them came in pairs to meet me; opened their files and after I had passed between them escorted me to the tent, where I was received by Mrs John Savile, and was obliged to address the Ladies in a Speech— A corvée from which I had hoped to escape— I spoke only about half a dozen Sentences to apologise for the absence of my wife; and to contrast the happiness of these times with the distressing period of 1775 and 1776. There was a dance on the green by the young Ladies of the Committee and about Sunset we repaired in procession from the green to the long Hall at French’s tavern. I then walked home and returned in the Carriage with Mary, Charles and his wife to the Hall— There was dancing and singing of Glees, till after the Curfew-Bell, when the Ladies first and then the men supped on cakes, fruit and limonade. I addressed the men and toasted the Ladies at the supper table— We came home about 10. P.M.
5. IV:30. Thursday.

The evening before last there was one of the most brilliant nocturnal Aurora’s that I ever be held— Not a Northern light, but a circle of luminous coruscations, gathering from the circumference of the horizon to the Zenith, with a various colouring of dark crimson, of black clouds and of dazzling light—altogether producing a degree of light surpassing that of the Moon at the full— Last evening there was also a brilliant northern light. This day was warm, damp, and cloudy, threatening rain, and with one short sprinkling about Noon; but cleared off cool at Sunset which I saw from Charles’s porch— The setting was however not cloudless.— Mr Billings called on me this morning, with his daughter Mrs Adeline Elizabeth Cary, as he had told me last Evening that he should— Mrs Cary is a widow and about fourteen months since had two sons enlisted as boys in the Navy. The eldest about 16 years old is now at Sea in the ship Ohio, the youngest about 14 is in the receiving ship at New-York, and as well as his mother extremely anxious to obtain his discharge— For this she applies to me; for my influence with the Secretary of the Navy, which I told her was just nothing at all— I promised however to write to the Secretary of the Navy, stating her wishes and those of her Son, and recommended to her to do the same; but she had no reason for claiming his discharge, but his own and her most earnest wish— She said she had been last week to New-York to see him, and found him very uneasy— One of his grievances was that he was obliged to eat his meals without any other table than the deck of the ship— I asked if he was out of health. She said he had been afflicted with worms; but she did not wish to have his health assigned as a reason for asking the discharge— Mr Billings is much opposed to asking the discharge, and last Evening hinted that he wished me to dissuade the Secretary of the Navy from granting it. He said this day that it would be better to urge him to send the boy immediately to sea, but the mother with tears in her eyes vehemently protested against this, and I shall do no such thing— I advised her to consider whether it would not be kinder to the boy himself to leave him to the fulfilment of his engagement; but I was not more successful with her, than I expect to be with the Secretary of the Navy— I spent this Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s with Mr. and Mrs De Wint, and Mrs John Angier from Medford who had arrived there this afternoon— Elizabeth had gone to Boston with Mr Lunt and returned home just before we came away— Mary and her daughter Mary-Louisa were there— Julia De Wint was at Mr Miller’s with Hannah— The Portrait in Crayons, of my father at the age of 30. was this day brought from Mr John Greenleaf’s— Mrs T. B. Adams claims it as having been given to her, by my mother with her own of the same date.— I admit the claim but the portrait of my father is now brought here to be engraved at the request of Mr George Bancroft. I received from the Revd. Doctor John Andrews of Newbury-Port this day 25 Letters from Edward Boylston, to Edward Wigglesworth, first Hollis Professor of Divinity at Harvard College—written from 1720 to 1728. from various places— I propose to notice them further to-morrow.
6. IV:15. Friday.
Sun rose 5:30. Set 6:28. Day 12 hours 58 minutes.

Mr and Mrs De Wint with Mrs T. B. Adams and Mrs. Angier were here this morning, and again in the afternoon and Evening with Elizabeth C. Adams to tea, and their Son John De Wint and their infant daughter and 11th. living child, Julia went this morning to visit Miss Guild at Brookline. They are all to take the cars to return home, to-morrow. Mr Cruft’s two Sons, William Smith and Samuel Breck, were also here this morning, and Mr Edward Brooks this afternoon— He had come out with Mrs Brooks to take tea with Charles and his wife; and Mr Brooks visited my garden, Nursery and Seminary seedlings— Mr Beale called here to say something about the lease to Solomon Hayden. He had some fears that the selectmen of the town might abuse their power of leasing for long terms the lands given by my father to the town, but I apprehend no such danger.
Edward Boylston’s Letters.

I have a Portrait of Edward Boylston given by Mr Ward Nicholas Boylston to my father— I know not precisely when nor why— Nor do I well know who Edward Boylston was— He is painted holding in his hand a Letter, directed To the Revd. Edward Wigglesworth Professor of Divinity—Cambridge, New-England— Last week Dr Andrews at Cambridge casually said, that among the papers, of his late wife’s father, the second Professor Wigglesworth were several Letters from Edward Boylston, but he knew not who he was— I requested of him as a favour the sight of them and received them from him yesterday— There are 24 Letters numbered by endorsement from 1. to 25. number 15 missing— The first is dated Boston April 14. 1720. and from internal evidence was directed to Mr Wigglesworth at Barnstable— There is an endorsement on it, in very small hand Letters from my dear deceased Friend, Mr Edward Boylston— The Letter is partly in Latin, and speaks of the writers mother, Cozin Betty and Esther (his Sister[)] names also Quincey and his mother. (This Quincey must have been Edmund the son of the Judge—[)] The second Letter dated Boston April 30. 1720. urges Mr Wigglesworth to come home, and promises to go out to meet him next Wednesday perhaps as far as Plymouth— Says they are in a sad seditious humour in Town owing to a pamphlet of Mr Colman’s, and speaks of a paper from our Sovereign Lords the People, directed to their Servants the Justices &c— The 3d. Letter dated Boston July 27. 1721. is directed, for Mr Edward Wigglesworth at College in Cambridge, speaks of having supplied several persons, and Plymouth County by means of Coll. Q. of the choice in his custody, with all proper precautions and obliterations— Perhaps Commencement Theses— He says he is now contriving a voyage to the Eastward with the Commissioners, and proposes to his Correspondent to make up with him a party of four—

N. 4. At home 2 O’Clock afternoon Augt. 4. 1721. Preparing to sail on the Eastern expedition. 5. Commissioners.— A Chaplain and Secretary of War— Wigglesworth to be the Chaplain 25 persons to go in the Sloop— At the head of the expedition was Coll. Hutchinson and Coll. Townsend was apparently one of the Commissioners (Further abstracts to-morrow.)
7. IV:30. Saturday.

Another sudden and great change in the temperature of the weather— After a Midsummer Night and Morning came an easterly wind shortly before noon, and a Sea Turn, or cold thick fog, about five this afternoon which continued all the evening— A Doctor Parsons of Providence Rhode Island called on me this morning, with his Son, a youth of 17. a Senior Sophister at Harvard University, to enquire, for the grave of William Tompson, one of the two first Ministers of the Church at Mount Wollaston— I read to them the note at page 34 of George Whitney’s History of Quincy, and described to them the spot in the burying yard where they would find the stone— Dr. Parsons said he had been in the Navy of the United States, and had published some medical work— That he had married a daughter of the late Doctor Holmes of Cambridge, whose wife was a daughter of Oliver Wendell, a son ofQuincy, daughter of the Agent Judge Edmund Quincy who died of the small-pox in London— The descent of this young Gentleman from the second Edmund Quincy, and from Henry Flint the other first Minister of the Mount Wollaston Church—and I understood Dr Parsons that he himself descended from Mr Tompson— They left me to go to the cemetery and I requested Dr. Parsons to communicate to me any interesting genealogical minutes which he might collect concerning the Wendell family—which he promised to do— Mrs Angier and Elizabeth C Adams dined with us— Their mother was unwell and did not come— At 5 this afernoon I went to the town Hall, where I found Mr Edward Miller, with the Selectmen Dr William B. Duggan and James Newcomb. The thirdBrown came in afterwards and also Mr G. W. Beale— I communicated to the Selectmen, the vote of the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund disapproving the projected lease to Solomon Hayden, and proposing one with a clause that if the parties at the expiration of the lease (20 years) cannot agree upon its renewal, the lessee may remove his buildings. We informed them also that the Supervisors disapproved another projected lease to John Whittier for 99 years, and recommended that no leases for long terms should be granted unless of lots for valuable dwelling houses, as yielding considerable ground rents— The Selectmen, appeared not to have been fully aware of their own responsibility both to the town, and to the Supervisors for the vigilant and profitable management of the property given by my father to the town— Mary, Charles and his wife spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s.
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth

N. 5. Boston October 9. 1721— He is going upon a journey to H—d (Hartford?) or W—d (Weathersfield?) about which, and his business there is mystery— He has mentioned only Rhode Island as the place he was bound to, and fears that the mention of any other now would raise more questions and speculations than he is writing to give occasion for— He says Dear Sir, you can’t imagine how much you have obliged me by your tender admonition: and then follows a strain of noble, benevolent, Christian philanthropic sentiment, indicating an amiable and public spirited disposition, truly worthy of the name of Boylston.
8. IV:45. Sunday

A gloomy day. Thick fog in the morning— Then distant thunder, and a succession of copious showers— All day, and Evening— Heard Mr. Lunt— His morning text was from James 5.11. [“]Ye have heard of the patience of Job”—this sermon was composed in consequence of a conversation at our table, upon an observation of Charles’s wife, that she did not think the book of Job sustained his reputation for Patience— The discourse was a critical review of the Book and of the character of Job. Ingenious—eloquent— pathetic— The anecdote of the banishment of Aristides, and the booby for whom he wrote his name on the shell, was introduced as a happy illustration— And the dying exclamation of Jesus “My God! My God! why hast thou forsaken me?[”] as an apposite vindication of Job, for some manifestation by him of indignant complaint by him at his sufferings— The afternoon text was from Genesis 49:4. “Unstable as Water, thou shalt not excel.”— This version of the common English Bible contains as Mr Lunt remarked, an admirable maxim of wisdom, applicable to every age of the world, and to every region of the globe— Whether it is in the Hebrew original, I know not, but in the Greek Septuagint it is not— In the French Genevan Bible it is rendered thou hast overflowed like water, and shalt not have the supremacy— But the thought is expressed in the English Bible with the most energy, and precision— Mr Lunt laid down the principle that instability is fatal to all excellence, and sustained it by great variety of illustration—concluding with an exhortation to the most important of all stabilities that of Religious Faith— I read the 7th. of Dr Parker’s Sermons—Joy in Heaven over the Penitent Sinner very good, but inferior to others of those that I had heard.— Charles was here this Evening, and we spent it by the bedside of his mother.— His Son John Quincy had dined with us. I wasted much time; reading in the second volume of Hutchinson’s History, particularly of the year 1721.
Edward Boylstons Letters to Edward Wigglesworth

N. 6. Boston Novr 13. 1721— Condoles with him on the decease of his Sister Madam Greaves.— Speaks of Wigglesworth’s appointment as Hollis professor of divinity, which had been made in that year—of Mr Hollis’s satisfaction with the appointment; and of the hope that he may be induced to increase the Salary of the professor from £40 to £80 a year— He says that [“]in Boston they can talk of nothing but inoculation—the success of which is increasing and he hopes will continue to increase.”— And yet, so infatuated are the people as to continue obstinate against the plainest experience (the only sure foundation in Physick[)]—but time will produce what nothing else can— The Letter refers also to the abominable Oath of the French Doctor Dalhonde, about the Battle of Almanza. The Letter is signed Edward Boylston—or as the heralds say—Boyldston.

This was the year in which Dr Zabdiel Boylston introduced the practice of inoculation into Boston— It appears by his pamphlet that on the 24th. of November, eleven days after the date of this Letter, he inoculated Mr. Edward Wigglesworth (Mr Hollis’s professor (aged) 32.[)] and Edmund, son of judge Edmund Quincy, then a student at Harvard College, and that they had the disorder very favourably— Edward Boylston had probably had the disease before— Dr Zabdiel Boylston was Edward’s Uncle.
9. IV:30. Monday

Weather variable— Cloud— Sunshine— Summer heat. Clear sky— Thick haze fog and star-light Evening— I had eight new rings, dug out about 3 feet deep in the seminary, for the purpose of raising upon them seedling fruit trees—from each hole, about five bushels of Stones were taken out, to be carried away, to be replaced with fertile soil, for I have invariably found that the seedlings thrive in proportion as the soil is refreshed and fattened. In the eight rings opened last year there are seedling peach apple and pear trees. 1 wild plum, 1 Althaea, 2 English Oaks. 3. Walnuts—2 strawberry vines planted last year—and one wild vine planted last June— A Cucumber vine from 2 seeds which I carelessly cast in last May, which has produced about a dozed Cucumbers used at table, and four already plucked for seed— A Squash vine casually cast in also last May, which has produced an abundance of barren, and two or three fruit bearing flowers, the fruit of which having no time to ripen will perish with the first frost— I have a multitude of seedlings of growth from 1to 9 years, but of which the peaches only bear fruit. Of 11 budded Baldwin apples imported from Medford in 1830. three girdled by field-mice have thrown up new shoots two of them below the bud; which I have again budded this year—the third is making a new stock of the Baldwin but Several of them bore this year but the late storm blew off almost all the fruit— My seminary is now wholly laid out in 8 rows of 8 rings each which I propose to cover if possible with 64 bearing fruit trees, besides the northern border. Charles and his wife were here this Evening.
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth

N. 7 Boston Fryday Night June 15th. 1722. Unintelligible— Addressed Dear Master; and closing with “my service to all Friends, and tell Cousin Quincey, how I sympathise with him under his Abstinence”— I suppose this was the Edmund Quincy who was graduated that year at Cambridge—

N. 8. Boston September 25th. 1722. Nearly as obscure as the preceding. He has determined to sail (he says not whither) and hopes to be ready in a month at farthest. He intreats his friend to make a short Discourse upon Jacob’s vow Gen: 28–20–21 and under a strong religious impression asks for his prayers— He announces as bad news that Messrs. Cutler, Whittlesey, Wetmore Johnson, Brown and Andrew have declared themselves (where?) for the Church of England.

N. 9. Barbados January 18th. 1722. Addressed For the Revd. Mr Edward Wigglesworth Hollisian professor of Divinity at Harvard College In Cambridge— He thanks his friend for a Letter of 22d. of November—refers him to another Letter written by the same occasion to his Mother; and gives an account of a College, undertaken in the Island of Barbados, but unfinished and the affairs of which go on very heavily. He adds the people there are said to expend 25 or 30 thousand pounds Sterl. a year for the Education of their children abroad, and wishes he may have influence enough to direct some of that money into Harvard College— He says that for his own ease he contrives to write upon one branch to one friend, upon another to a second—and so on.
10. IV:15. Tuesday
Sun rose 5:34. Set 6:21. Day 12 hours 47: minutes.
Mary’s birthday 32 and her daughter Fanny’s 9.

Charles and his wife went to Medford, to spend some days, with her father Mr Peter C. Brooks, taking their Son John Quincy with them— My wife and Mary, with her daughter Mary-Louisa and John Quincy, went with Mrs Charles in the Carriage to Boston; I went with Charles in his four wheeled Chaise, in getting out of which at Dr Frothingham’s door I narrowly escaped for the second time a severe, if not fatal accident—beware of the third! I went to Mr Bancroft’s to tell him that I had, coming into town the Portrait of my father in Crayons, done in 1764. and would send it to him— He has engaged an engraver by the name of Storm to engrave it— Mr Bancroft read to me part of a chapter of his History, that he is now composing about the English Revolution of 1688 and the character of William the 3d.— I thought the character much too favourable, and recommended to him to read Cerisier and D’Estrades for the History of William in Holland, and especially his base ingratitude to John de Witt, and the share that he had in the horrible murder of him and his brother— I told him that as a champion of Liberty William the 3d. was the greatest impostor in human history— He promised to qualify some of his praise and sharpen some of his censure— I called a second time at Dr Frothingham’s, but the ladies had not yet landed— I went to Mr Blagden’s the Minister of the Old South Church, and requested to see his Church Record of baptisms which he very cheerfully shewed me, and there I immediately found the two following entries
1685 June 7th. Hañah daughter of Daniel and Hañah Quinsey
1689. July 28. Johnof Daniel and Hañah Quinsey

I told Mr Blagden that here were two mistakes in the record; the name both of the wife and daughter of Daniel Quinsey having been Anna, and not Hannah, but I added how much I was delighted to have found where my ancestor, whose name I bear was baptized— He said he was equally gratified to find the name upon the record of his church— I mentioned the mistake into which Mr Wisner had fallen in the note pageof his history of the Church; and the statement in the Letter of Chief Justice Sewall to his Son in 1720. that Dr Leonard Hoare had preached for a short time at this Church as an assistant to Mr Thacher in 1672.— The name of Leonard Hoare, is upon the book as a member of the Church, admitted in November 1772— My next call was at Lincoln and Reed’s shop where I directed the box containing the silver tea-pot sugar-bason and cream pot which I had taken, to be sent to Dr. Frothingham’s.— A few minutes at Charles’s Office where for the first time I saw Mr Spooner— Then at Cunningham’s Auction room where I took a Catalogue of Theodore Lyman’s library to be sold to-morrow—some of which I marked with a pencil, at Dr Frothingham’s, for Charles to bid for if he comes into town to-morrow— We met at Dr Frothingham’s a Mr Dunkin from Charleston, said to be Chancellor of the State of South-Carolina— Abby left us to proceed to Medford, and I came home with the Ladies, to dine at three. Charles’s children Louisa and Charles dined with us— Weather growing cool and fair.
11. III:30. Wednesday
Sun rose 5:35. Set 6:19. Day 12 hours 44 minutes

Mr David Loud came, and I gave him the Deed of his military bounty Land in Arkansas of which I had received the exemplification from the Commissioner of the General Land-Office Mr James Whitcomb— Mr Loud had received some information that the Government had taken some of this Land for a fort; concerning which I promised to make enquiry at Washington, next winter and to give him information at Braintree by Letter— Morning visit from a Mr Alden from Western Pennsylvania, who announced himself as a Son of the late Revd. Timothy Alden President of Meadville College, and author of the compilation of Epitaphs, and a Coll. Cowan of Virginia, removed ten years ago to Missouri— Their visit was of mere curiosity and civility— Their personal appearance characteristic of New-England and Virginia— Alden Middle-sized, plump, boasting of his Yankee blood, and quoting Virgil for the verse Dulce et Decorum est pro patria mori. Cowan six foot six inches long; slender as a stalk of Carolina corn—round shouldered; lantern jawed, with a weary, worn out and yet good natured countenance, and gentlemanly deportment— Mr John A. Green Editor of the Quincy Patriot came to request me to deliver a Lecture before the Quincy Lyceum—who are about to recommence their Winter entertainment— He said they understood I had undertaken to deliver a Lecture at Braintree, and it would be perfectly satisfactory if I would repeat the same here; which I accordingly promised to do— Elizabeth C. Adams was here at tea.
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth.

N. 10. Barbados March 18 1722/3 Politics— Much surprized at the Governor (Shute)’s having left his charge; and afraid that the appointment of a Stranger (Anthony Sanderson a merchant of London) as agent for the Province at London, instead of Dummer, will so offend him that their joint influence at Court will be fatal to the Charter— The following passage in the Letter is remarkable— “And they tell me, the Ministry have a very watchful eye, upon our growth; apprehending formidable notions of what may happen many years hence unless we are taken care of in season and theyll strain? an occasion to do yt[”];— He fears they will be reduced to the condition of the Island of Barbados; and says “Most of the Posts of profit here are patented in England, and farm’d out again to the highest bidder and you may be sure without any regard to his qualifications; but I wish and hope for better things to my dear Country.”

He refers to another Letter to his Uncle Boylston, and announces his intention to stay a year longer in Barbados, and about July of the next ensuing year to embark directly for England—because the direct trade between New England and Barbados on their own accounts, is too small to promise a prospect of Fortune to be made by mercantile business. In the mean time he hopes for consignments which will give opportunities of acquiring the confidence of his friends in New-England—

This Letter corroborates the narrative of Hutchinson of the dissensions between the Colonial House of Representatives and Governor Shute—and shews the jealousy, prevailing even then at the English Court against New-England.
12— IV. Thursday
Sun rose 5:36. clear. Sat 6:17. beclouded. Day 12 hours 41 minutes

Morning visit from Mr Amos Lawrence and Mrs Dexter— Charles came in from Boston, and dined and spent the Evening with us. Deacon Spear was here this afternoon, and shewed me the plan of a road projected by Mr Francis Jackson and Harvey Field, from Captain’s Bridge to Spear’s house, passing through acres of my land, and cutting up my grounds without mercy. Harvey Field besieged me to give the land for this road two or three years since; but I was inaccessible— I told the Deacon now, that I wanted no road through any of my Lands and would give no land for any road. The Town and the County Commissioners might lay out what they pleased of roads— I would not favour any; nor oppose any— I was willing any of my land should be taken for a reasonable compensation, which might be useful to the public— I would interpose no obstacle, and leave all to the County Commissioners— I would take no part in any road speculation. He said Mr Willard had enquired if I would sell two or three acres of my quarry land adjoining that where he is now at Work— I told him my price was 1000 dollars an acre for 10. acres and I did not wish to dispose of the land in driblets— Visit from Mr Gouverneur Kemble who is travelling with his brother-in-Law the Secretary of the Navy Paulding; and with his Sisters— He thinks opinions have changed in New-York and are now in favour of the Independent Treasury; and that the Slaves of the Spanish Slave ship who mutinied and captured here and have been brought into New-London, must be delivered up to the Government of the Island of Cuba.— I fear they will be.— Mr Kemble and his family party go for New-York to-morrow morning
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth.

N. 11. Barbados May 29th. 1723. The first part of this Letter relates to his business; which was to dispose of Fish consigned to him from New-England and in which he had been very unfortunate. The market was overstocked; and the Articles perished by the heat of the climate— Then comes an account of the State of religion, and character of the clergy in the Island—Melancholy—11. Parishes, two of them with two churches in each, the rest one in each— Divine service twice every Lord’s day— In the town, two Sermons—in the country parishes only prayers in the afternoon— The Clergy lead licentious lives—Swear—drink, commit adultery—one then under prosecution for that crime.

N. 13 “I observe how merry you and Mother had made yourselves about my Picture, and in truth I expected that the Superscription of the Letter in my hand, would have raised that dispute; and since you have left it to my arbitration I pray that the award may be deferr’d until my return home, which I don’t expect will be much sooner than this time two years, a great while forwards I confess! But I can’t tell how to help it now.[”]— He was destined never to return!— That Picture is now in my possession.— There is something said of a K—g Street Affair—and he prays to hear from his correspondent.
13. IV. Friday

A cold autumnal day—and we had fire in the dining room. My seminary is now laid out in 8 rows each of 8 rings, each bearing or to bear a seedling fruit tree; besides the northern border. I began this plan in the autumn of 1834 when the border and the first two rows of rings were laid out— There was one row, next to the fence at the road already and I have added one row of rings each year since 1834— Setting out in each ring a peach, cherry or black walnut seedling tree from the garden or Nursery; and strewing Apple and Pear seeds—Peach and Plum stones—Acorns and walnuts in the rings round the trees— The ground beneath the surface is perfectly paved with loose stones of every size, from gravel to 50 pounds weight. Kirk has now dug out, filled up with manure and dressed the last row of rings Each ring is a circular hole of about four feet diameter, dug three feet deep, and filled up with manure, and fresh earth mixed up with the old soil sifted from five bushels of stones carted away— I spend an hour of morning twilight for exercise, in labour upon these rings. In ring 8 of row 6. there is a wild strawberry vine, the root of which on theof June last I brought over from the hill, and set out, and which has been slowly creeping along till this day; and there are 3 poor apple seedlings, sown last autumn upon it. I dressed it this morning; sowed round it a circle of 13 english Oak acorns and 4 peach stones—and in an extra ring near the road, Southeast corner of the seminary 10 English Oak Acorns, and 4 peach stones— Charles dined and spent the Evening with us. I saw a beautiful Sunset from his porch— Finished reading the second Volume of Prescott’s Ferdinand and Isabella and resumed the biography of my father.
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth.

N 12. Barbados July 10th. 1723. Distressed by false reports to his disadvantage, circulated at Boston by a Captain Cussens and has determined to leave Barbados, and return home— The K—g S— affair still mysterious— Needs not ask his correspondent’s prayers for his good voyage—will have them without it.
N. 13. At Sea— N. Lat: 37. Long: W. from Lon: 54. May 9th. 1724.
St. John’s (Newfoundland[)] May 19th. 1724

This Letter begun at Sea, and finished ten days after in the Island of Newfoundland, is in answer to two received before he left Barbados— It relates to the personal affairs of Mr Wigglesworth; the increase of his Salary, and his inclination to marry Boylston’s Sister Esther—which he warmly encourages— He expresses his astonishment at the choice of Dr. Cook as the agent of the Province at London— The second Letter merely announces his arrival the day before at St John’s, and his receiving there from his correspondent, a Letter and 2. pamphlets.

N. 14. St. John’s October 16th. 1724. Very short, apologizing for not having time to answer his Letters as he would wish to do. It would seem that the damsel (Esther) had rejected the Professor of divinity’s addresses.— She says if he was at home he would teach her better.— He hopes his visit to London won’t be to the professor’s disservice; and thinks Mr Hollis should be grateful for the honour done him by the Professor in refusing the invitation of Yale College— Also that the government of Harvard College is bound to make his post as honourable and profitable as that which at their instance he had refused.
N. 15. Missing. (apparently written from Lisbon.)
14. IV. Saturday
Mrs T. B. Adams
Sun rose 5:38. Set 6:14. Day 12 hours 36 minutes.

Mary went with Elizabeth C. Adams, on a visit to Mrs John Angier at Medford— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine, with his wife, and son John Quincy from their visit to Mr P. C. Brooks at Medford— Morning autumnal cold— I dressed ring 7. row 1. where a seedling pear-tree was set out last fall—which has outlived this summer but pines. Mrs T. B. Adams and Julia De Wint came to spend a few days with us while Mary and Elizabeth are at Medford— This afternoon Mr George Fuller with a Mr Hunnewell, a son of Jonathan Hunnewell came and informed me that the judge of Probate for the County of Worcester had granted Letters of administration upon both the Estates of Governor Gill, and of the late Moses Gill to Mr Fuller, and he shewed me both the Letters dated the 4th. of this month— I then engaged to present my account of Administration of Thomas Boylston, on Monday the 23d. instt. to the judge of Probate at Boston, and Mr Fuller engaged to attend in support of the claim in the right of Governor Gill, and of the late Moses Gill— I began reading the 3d. volume of Prescott’s History of Ferdinand and Isabella— I saw the Sun rise and Set clear from Charles’s porch. Spent the Evening with the Ladies at Charles’s— Brilliant Northern Light.
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth.

N. 16. Exon March 16th. 1724/5 Refers to another long Letter written by him from Lisbon. Has received two Letters from his correspondent, since his arrival in England, forwarded to him from London, by his uncle Boylston— Has received Letters with recommendations from Coll. Quincy, Mr Colman and Mr Flynt— Landed at Dartmouth the 4th. of the Month and came to Exeter the next day, with Letters from Lisbon to most of the top merchants of the place.— He intends to stay there till the 22d and then go to London by the way of Bristol, Bath and Oxford— And to come directly home from London, dropping Newfoundland if possible.— The famous Mr Peirce of Exeter sent him an invitation to his house, and he paid him a visit of more than two hours and intends to visit him again, and to tell him that Mr Colman has been chosen President of Harvard College— Hopes he will accept and that his Church will consent. Regrets that some of the leading men of the Assembly are enemies of the College—
N. 17. London May 28th. 1725. Addressed My Dear Friend—and June 1. Tuesday.

Has visited all the remarkable places 15 or 20 miles round London— England is a fine place; full of every thing to gratify all the various inclinations of human nature; provided you have (the causa sine qua non) cash enough— Is mortified to bid adieu to this Garden in exchange for the rocks and shelves of Newfoundland— But comforts himself that it will bring him nearer to the arms of his dear friends in New-England.— No books printing to which the dissenting Clergy are likely to subscribe.— Will leave his correspondent’s name with his Landlord Samuel Clarke, a bookseller to subscribe for him, when any such book is about.

June 1 There has been a hearing before a Committee of the Lords of the Council— Lords in good humour because the Agent’s Council disclaimed all the Colonial Assembly’s Memorial except negativing the Speaker. Has been with Mr Hollis at the Coffee house, but did not venture to speak to him of the Professor’s Affairs— Mr Hollis is soured. Proposition made to Mr Oliver; to have done with rambling; its pleasures, pains and inconveniences.
15. IV:15. Sunday

Heard Mr Lunt— Morning Sermon, from Matthew 28.8 “And they departed from the Sepulchre with fear, and great joy”— The first part of the discourse was a commentary upon the event narrated in the chapter of which the text forms a part, remarking upon the simplicity of the narrative as furnishing luminous evidence of its credibility, and pointing to the nature of this fact, as exactly suited to produce the mingled sensations of fear and joy in the two women, at the sight of the Angel, and the hearing of his words. And thence he passed to a general deduction that this mingled emotion of fear and joy, is the temper with which the Christian should be impressed by all the important truths of religion—as the existence of God, his attributes of power—and of Justice—as the immortality of the Soul, and a future state of retribution— In the afternoon Mr Whitney preached from Luke 16.27. “Then he said, I pray thee therefore, father, that thou wouldest send him to my father’s house; 28 For I have five brethren; that he may testify unto them, lest they also come into this place of torment.” The parable of the rich man and Lazarus. Mr Whitney’s improvement of this story was. 1. That it was not because Dives was rich, that he went to Hell—nor because Lazarus was poor that he went at once into Abraham’s bosom. This must be true—but it is remarkable that the contrast presented in the parable is exclusively of riches and poverty— Not one word is said of the merits of Lazarus or of the demerits of Dives.— The pampered enjoyments of the rich man and the beggary, and sufferings of the poor man, are exclusively the theme of the tale— In the world of real life, riches are often the reward of superior virtue—the fruits of industry, economy, prudence, temperance, justice, fortitude—and in the infinite variety of chances in human life, the practice of virtue is the most successful avenue to wealth, as beggary, and abject poverty are prima facie indications of vice— 2 That in this parable the doctrine of future punishments and rewards is most explicitly declared by Christ, is to my mind undeniable— The denial of it is to me but a form of Atheism. Yet I will not deny that a universalist may be a Christian á sa maniere, as the Spanish Bishop at Astorga, said to the Priest, of my father— 3. That the rich man of the parable, had one very amiable virtue, manifested by his affectionate concern for his five brothers.— Mr Whitney believes in the final salvation of all men; and although I cannot find it in the gospel, I hope it may be true— I once heard Mr Whitney put in a plea for Judas Iscariot— Just before the close of the Evening service, Mr Lunt gave notice that on this day fortnight, the second centurial anniversary of the gathering of the Church at Mount Wollaston he proposed to notice the fact in the services of the day; and that both the Pastors of the Church thought it would be a fitting occasion, for administering the Communion; it being only an anticipation of one week upon the usual day— He put it therefore to vote, to the members of the Church present, and it was a vote without opposition. I read Dr Parker’s 8th. Sermon, on the aids and encouragements in the way of virtue. Charles’s sons John and Charles dined with us and went with me, morning and afternoon to meeting— Mr Beale and his Son George were here this Evening—
16. IV:15. Monday.

I noticed the brilliant Northern light of Saturday Evening. It continued through the Night, and when I rose yesterday morning, was brighter than when I had left it on retiring to bed. It was yesterday truly a Boreal Aurora; but as the dawn advanced suddenly vanished leaving a Crystal clear sky— There was again a Northern light last Evening and there has indeed been one almost every evening the last ten days— This morning by way of varying my exercise, I walked at the dawn to the 6th. Milestone towards Boston 46 minutes— My quick pace is still 17 minutes to a mile and 1070 paces on level ground and hard earth and cool temperature and calm weather, and light shoes.— But hilly ground, dusty or muddy road, sultry weather, or a brisk gale, or heavy shoes increase the number of paces sometimes to 1120.— The dust this morning and gravel in my shoes gave me 1090 paces from the 7th. to the 6th. milestone and 1110 returning.— Mr James H. Foster with his daughter Mary paid us a morning visit. Mrs Foster is in very bad health— Charles and his wife went this afternoon to Brookline, but returned to tea and spent the Evening here. I received this day, the Genius of universal emancipation N. 314. printed at Hennepin Illinois announcing the death of Benjamin Lundy, a pure and noble spirit as ever lived— He has left none better behind.
Letters of Edward Boylston to Edward Wigglesworth

N. 18. Deal June 5th. 1725. directed to Mr Edward Wigglesworth, at Mr Flynt’s, Queen Street Boston—very short—merely to announce, that he came down the river to embark at Gravesend and found at Greenwich a vessel from Boston, with a Letter from his correspondent on board— Has not ventured to speak to Mr Hollis about the professorship, in consequence of the management of the Assembly when Mr Colman was chosen President.

N. 19. Livorno May 2d N.S. 1726.— This is the longest and most interesting Letter of the collection— He arrived at Leghorn, in the latter end of December (where he was from June 1725 when he was at Deal does not appear) about the middle of February he went to Civita Vecchia, and thence to Rome, where he spent near two months; visiting the curiosities antient and modern of the place; and in constant intercourse with a round number of very ingenious English Gentleman Travellers, among whom he was pretty much of a rarity and was chiefly known by the name of the American— But his Coffee man, in making out his bill dubbed him Monsr. lé Chevalier Africane. At Rome he witnessed the extravagant and costly absurdities of the Carnival— After which he diligently applied himself to the virtue of travellers, and visited with his antiquary the temples, churches, palaces, Villa’s— The Pantheon, the Temple of Vesta, the Amphitheatre of Vespasion, Triumphal Arches, Columns, Aqueducts, Baths, and all the marvels of the eternal City.— He had frequent opportunities of seeing the Pope; and his favourite Cardinal Cocci— Also the Pretender of whose condition at that time he gives some account— Says his dear Master Wigglesworth shall hear from him again at St. John’s where he is bound in 4 or 5 days.
17. IV. Tuesday

Call from Minott Thayer, to enquire for a form of petition to the Secretary of War, in behalf of Asa Copeland a revolutionary pensioner at Braintree who has lost his certificate— The form is in one of the documents of the 2d Session of the 25th. Congress, but I neglected to have them sent round from Washington. Mr Thayer had a copy of the certificate, and I told him the form of the Petition would not be material— Mr Thayer spoke of the recent Convention of whig young Men at Worcester, and of their Resolutions— A Steam engine to navigate a cockboat— A convocation of 700 delegates to pass resolutions upon nothing and pledge the electoral vote of the State at the next Presidential election, to William Henry Harrison or Henry Clay, at the pleasure of a National Convention to be held next December at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania— Mr Thayer shook his head, and sighed that the power of the State had passed from the old standards into the hands of young men; which in peaceable and prosperous times is the natural course of events. I told him I hoped to be able shortly to fix upon the day for the delivery of my lecture to the Lyceum at Braintree— Mr Lunt was here this afternoon on a visit with his mother. I walked again this morning to the 6th. milestone and back, with the same result clogged with dust—making 1100 paces to the mile, but precisely 46 minutes out— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Took with him Julia De Wint, who is on her way home to Fishkill landing— He went in the Evening to Edmund Quincy’s— His wife here.
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth.

N. 20. St. John’s August 4th. 1726— He arrived from Italy the 13th. of the preceding month— Congratulates his correspondent upon his approaching marriage. Says the youngsters at Cambridge are said to practice upon the bedpost before Commencement. He intends to return home, that Fall.
N. 21. St John’s Newfoundland Novr. 1. 1726. After his correspondent’s marriage

Much merriment about the marriage of Danforth— Something about War, and Peace with the Eastern Indians— Asks for his correspondents thoughts on the present state of their money or Medium of Exchange. He quotes Dick Steeles obituary of Partridge; and Leontine and Eudoxus in the 123d number of the Spectator.— He is going again to England by invitation of his friend Mr Wilks. he knows not for what purpose but relies upon his honour not to have sent for him, unless for some valuable consideration. Hopes to be more serviceable with Mr Hollis, to his correspondent than when he was in England before, and asks to be put in a way how to be so—

N. 22. London February 15th. 1726/7 Addressed Dear Mr Wigglesworth and directed To the Reverend Mr Wigglesworth S.T.P.—Cambridge. New-England— The invitation of Mr Wilks, was for a proposal of partnership with him at London, which was accepted, and Articles had accordingly been executed— He gives a detail of his reasons for contracting this engagement—the Newfoundland business being a drudgery—without profit or pleasure; and Commission business in Boston not much better— He has struggled with his fondness for his Country; and anxious that his mother should be reconciled to his new condition as likely to enable him to be more serviceable to her. He is to go to Boston in the fall to strengthen Correspondence and settle with his late partner Mr Gowan. He has been frequently in company with Mr Hollis, but for want of directions could deal only in generalities Encloses a pamphlet on the confused State of Europe, between Peace and War.
18. IV. Wednesday

Heavy rain great part of the night and continued the early part of this day. The grass was so wet that I did not venture out upon it; but kept house nearly the whole day. Mrs T. B. Adams dined at Charles’s, and we all spent the Evening there— Mr Lunt called this afternoon, and returned me the volume of Sermons containing that of Mr John Hancock on the decease of judge Edmund Quincy in Feby 1738. which I wanted to return to the Historical Society— He wanted 3 manuscripts which are at the Historical Society— Mr Wheelwright’s notorious Sermon, Mr Fairfields Diary, and Mr Fiske’s Artillery election Sermon; all which I promised to endeavour to procure for him— I answered a Letter from the Revd. Mr Blagden.
Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth.

N 23. London March 20th. 1726/7 almost entirely upon politics; the reigning topic, he says of conversation in London, and he supposes to be so in New England. His speculations are sensible and judicious; but not altogether prophetic— He thinks the Emperor will give up the trade from Ostend to the East Indies rather than risque the Austrian Netherlands falling into the hands of France; as they probably might in the case of a rupture. He fears that England will be compelled to restore Gibraltar perhaps under the mediation of the French king—and he speaks of an insolent Memorial and Letter presented to the king and dispersed among the People by the Emperor’s Resident at London (Palms— See Smolletts continuation of Hume Book 2. Ch. 3. p 337) He mentions a remarkable romantic address from Totness. In a postscript he announces the death of the Great Sir Isaac Newton

N. 24 Barbados. April 12th 1728. Announces his arrival in that island on the first of that month (of all daies in the year) and met with an exceeding low market—full as low as he expected; but that being a thing he had bin used to there it might be expected that he had learnt patience to bear these misfortunes.— He hardly knows how long his stay will be in Barbados, but hopes to be more particular by the next ship for Boston

N 25. and last. Barbados July 4th. 1728— He says he has not received a line from his correspondent since he left Boston— Whence it appears that since his Letter of March 20. 1727 from London, he had returned to Boston and thence had come to Barbados— In this Letter he asks to be informed who had been chosen fellow of the College in Mr Welsleed’s room— Whether Governor Burnet had arrived (he arrived 13. July 1728) and whether he makes a second Mecenas to Alma Mater and her Posterity— He mentions having lent Mr Dummer’s defence of the Colonial Charters to Mr Samuel Osborne, perhaps the richest man in the Island who had acquired his fortune by his industry, and had never been out of the West Indies— And he gives an extract of a note from Mr Osborne to him on returning the pamphlet, expressing the wish that all the colonies had royal charters similar to ours
I believe that soon after the last of these Letters Edward Boylston was lost at Sea. Mr Wilks his last partner was Francis Wilks, agent of the Province.
19. V:45. Thursday

I went in the Carriage this morning to Boston and called at Mr Bond’s shop, where I left my Chronometer, which for the last fortnight has been disordered— He asked me to leave it with him about a fortnight and gave me a watch to use in the meantime— He shewed me a circular signed bySmyth Foreign Secretary and a Letter from Sir J. F. W. Herschel to him requesting him to take part in a concert of observations upon magnetism at numerous stations in all parts of the world, undertaken upon the report of a Committee of the Royal Society and of which there is something in the papers sent to me with the Letter of the Astronomer Royal George Biddell Airy, of 8. June last. But Mr Bond has not yet received the Report of the Committee of the Royal Society I spoke to Mr Bond of President Quincy’s project for an Observatory at Cambridge to the execution of which I fear there is some obstacle— I stop’d at the Office of the Merchant’s Insurance Company to enquire for Mr Nathanial Curtis, but he was not there. Then I went to the Massachusetts Historical Society, where Mr Snelling gave me the copy which he has made for me, of my father’s controvery in 1773. with General Thomas Brattle; and for which I paid him ten dollars— I enquired for the three manuscripts which Mr Lunt wished me to procure for him, but Mr Snelling could not find them— He did find however a manuscript of 1672. consisting of abstracts of all the Sermons preached at the South Church from June till December 1672— More than half of them were preached by Dr Leonard Hoar, beginning, on the 21st. of July, and continuing till the 15th of December— There are 20 Sermons. 4 from 2. Peter 3.11—one from Psalm 93.5 Eight from Micah 7.18. One from Psalm 60:2. One from Cant: 5.16—and five from Psalm 19.12. all excellent texts; though the manuscript was so difficult to read, and I had so little time that I only took time to minute down the texts and the dates— I went next to the Statehouse to find Dr T. M. Harris but he was not there— But I found Mr Joseph B. Felt there and examined with him the manuscript Records of the General Court from 1710 to 1757. One of my objects was to ascertain when the public service of Coll John Quincy ceased and also when the change was made in the spelling of the Quincy name. Coll John Quincy was first elected a Representative in the House for the town of Braintree, and his name is entered Quincey— But in the same year in November the name of Edmund Quincy as a member of the Council is spelt without the e— John Quincy’s service in the Council ceased with the year 1753 in 1755 and 56 he was again member of the House from Braintree, after which his name is no longer seen— Dr Parkman, whom I met in the street went with me to the City Council chamber, where I went chiefly to see if I could find on the records the nativity of Edward Boylston— I found 22. Novr. 1698 Edward, son of Edward and Mary Boylston— Also Hannah 30. Septr 1695 and Thomas 15 Jany 1700— I found also the names of 8 children of Zabdiel and Jerusha Boylston. After a short call from Dr George Parkman with Coll Bomford’s Son, I went to Dr. Frothinghams where I found Mary and Elizabeth C. Adams, with whom I came home to Quincy to dinner. Mrs T. B. Adams was gone home. Charles, his wife and three children dined with us— Saw the Sun set clear from his porch—
20. IV:15. Friday

I transplanted a wild plum seedling from a flower pot, into ring 1. row 7. and in the same ring I planted 4 Medford Peach Stones, and 4 immature English white Oak Acorns. The fruit of several of our peach trees is now ripe, and others are daily ripening, and in great abundance— I found in the garden border, next the kitchen gate a 4th. shagbark walnut, just out of the ground planted last Fall— Among of the secrets of nature one of the most unaccountable to me is the infinite variety of process in the growth of plants, and that which most moves my special wonder is that of the same tree one will grow in a summer more feet than another will reach in inches I found this morning on my table a pamphlet copy of the pension Laws now in force, a document of the 2d. Session of the 25th Congress, which Mr Minott Thayer wanted when he was here last Tuesday, but which I could not then find— I rode over to his house this afternoon in the Carriage, taking Charles’s son John with me, and leaving Mary at Mrs. T. B. Adams’s and Louisa C. Smith at Mr John Greenleaf’s. I left the document with Mr Thayer; and on my return, walked from Mr J. Greenleaf’s home— Charles’s wife and Miss Mary P. Hall, her cousin who is upon a visit to her spent the Evening here, and Charles came in at its close, having been at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I answered Mr Blagden’s Letter, and sent him the copy of chief Justice Sewall’s Letter ofApril 1721 to his Son— I am approaching to the close of Prescott’s History of Ferdinand and Isabella, which retains its interest even after the close of the life of that incomparable woman— It gives me new views of a very important period of the History of Europe—and a more familiar acquaintance than I had ever before attained of the characters not only of Ferdinand and Isabella, but of Gonzalvo of Cordova the great Captain, the Wellington of his Age, of Christopher Columbus, and of Cardinal Ximenes the three shining lights of Spain in that century. The subordinate characters of Joanna Beltraneja, of the Infanta Joanna the crazy mother of Charles the 5th and her despicable husband Philip of Austria, of Navarro the Engineer, of Germaine de Foix the second wife of Ferdinand, of Louis the 12th. of France, whom Mr Prescott strips of all his spurious honours, as the Pere du Peuple, of the noble Marchioness of Moya, Isabella’s ever devoted friend, are all brought into fresh and vivid recollection— The wonder almost inconceivable, is how a person of such a spirit, could have been produced parents; and in the midst of such a course have been bred to such a glorious reign, adorned with such a train of virtues, and with so little of the dross of the age in which she lived. Dr Clark when his wife died fancied that he had left his Soul— Ferdinand in the death of Isabella certainly lost his— I want translations of the Spanish and Italian quotations of Mr Prescott and there should be maps of Spain and Italy at least to illustrate the narrative. The Conquest of Grenada of Naples and of Navarro give a splendid colouring to the Story— The least laboured part is the discovery and adventures of Columbus.
21. IV:10. Saturday
Sun rose 5:45. Set 6:2. Day 12 hours 17 minutes.

Mrs Lawrence came to obtain my assistance if possible for procuring a renewal of her pension; for the service of her husband in the last War with Great Britain— I promised to look up at the next Session of Congress her old petition—and present it to the house; and if it should not be on the files or if additional vouchers should be missing, to write to her under cover to her son, James Monroe Lawrence at Boston, with whom she occasionally resides— But I could give her no encouragement to expect that her application will be successful— Mr Lunt called this afternoon, and left with me a small volume of the Cambridge Church Records; a document more confused and chaotic than those of Braintree or of Milton— It goes back to about 1656. and contains minutes of births—marriages, admissions to the Church, ownings of the Covenant—and then loads of wood given to the ministers, receipts for Salary, dates of planting and sowing them in the spring, and minutes of stirring events as they occurred— A Church record of this kind systematically kept would be a jewel— Mr Lunt borrowed this book of Mr Newell, the Minister of the Church at Cambridge, with whom he proposes to exchange to-morrow, and he left it with me, supposing I might have some curiosity to examine it— Among the entries there was a Letter from Dr Ezra Stiles, President of Yale College, to Timothy Hilliard, copied in the hand writing of the late Dr Holmes, giving an extract from Winthrop’s Journal, of 1. Feby 1636—the account of the formation of the Church at Newtown (Cambridge) and the election of Thomas Shepard as Pastor— The Letter of Dr Stiles was written before the publication of Winthrop’s Journal, but of which he had seen the manuscript. There are also in the book a number of entries of baptisms; admissions to the church and marriages of persons by the name of Adams from Anne wife of John Adams, admitted to full communion 17. June 1660. to the marriage of John Adams and Hannah Phelps 6. July 1786. Mr Lunt said he would call for the book to-morrow morning on his way to Cambridge, as Mr Newell wished to have it returned to him— After dinner I took a ride with Charles in his four wheeled Chaise round over Milton Hill— Stopped on the way at Mr Billings’s, and enquired if his daughter Mrs Cary was there— He said she was in Boston— I read to him the answer received this morning from Commodore Chauncy, to my application at the request, of Mrs Cary, for the discharge of her Son, from the Navy-Yard at New-York where he is engaged as an Apprentice. The answer is that Commodore Ridgely has been directed to discharge Thomas Webb Cary, provided there be no particular reason for retaining him— Charles and his wife and Miss Hall spent the Evening here. On Thursday night there was a Ball and Supper at French’s tavern exclusively confined to the Stone cutters, and from which all the Irish were excluded— They met about nine in the Evening upon which a salute of 26 guns was fired: and the salute was repeated yesterday morning, just before Sunrise; as they were breaking up.— I suppose it was a set-off to the Pic-Nic.
22. IV. Sunday.

Mr Lunt did not call this morning for the volume of Cambridge Church Records, but I was engaged almost all the morning in examining it and in extracting all its entries of the name of Adams, though I believe none of them were of the lineage of our old Henry Adams of Mount Wollaston. There were undoubtedly of the primitive patriarchal age of the New England Colony, many others of the name of Adams— Mr Newell preached here this morning from 1. Corinthians 13.9. “For we know in part, and we prophesy in part 10. But when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away. 11. When I was a child I spoke as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child: but when I became a man, I put away childish things. 12. For now we see through a glass darkly; but then, face to face: now I know in part; but then shall I know, even as also I am known.” Nothing remarkable in this Sermon— Mr Newell dined with us— I invited also Mr Whitney, but he declined saying that he always dined at home on Sundays— Mr Newell’s afternoon text was Genesis 2.15. [“]And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the Garden of Eden, to dress it and to keep it.” Same character as the discourse of the morning. Mr Newell took home with him the manuscript volume of Cambridge Church records. Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with us— Tea and Evening at Charles’s. Mr E. Price Greenleaf came in. Mr Degrand as usual brought out a large budget of Newspapers— The Steamship British Queen, arrived Friday afternoon at New-York, bringing 209 passengers in 17 days. This is now the average passage of the Steamers from England— The average passage out is 14 days. The Steam navigation has thus abridged the distance across the atlantic more than one half; for in the most improved state of previous Navigation the outward average passage of the packet ships was 30 and the return passage 37. days. The multiplication of travellers is proportioned to the increased expedition of travel. The queen Victoria’s Speech at the close of the Session of Parliament is brought out by this vessel, and portends the continuance of Peace— The controversies between the kingdoms of Belgium and of Holland have been adjusted—and the five powers, Britain, France, Prussia, Austria and Russia, have combined to maintain the Independence of the Mahometan Turkish Empire against the rebellious Bashaw of Egypt— A Christian league for the preservation of a Mahometan Empire— The queen declares also her determination to persevere in her efforts to persuade all the Christian powers to abolish the Slave-trade. It is hardly conceivable that if the British Government were sincere in their zeal for the abolition of the Slave trade, they should after so many years of negotiation have accomplished nothing but Treaties. The British Nation drive their Government along in this Career; but the Government never have been and never will be hearty in the cause— I read this evening the 9th. of Dr Parker’s Sermons; to prove that righteousness is the test of the Christian Character— The deeper I penetrate into these Discourses, the more light and superficial they appear.
23. IV:15 Monday.
Sun rose 5:47. Set 5:58. Day 12 hours 11 minutes.

Engaged yesterday from the morning hour of meeting, till 9 in the Evening, at public worship and in company, my record and my correspondence runs in arrear— The interruptions of this day kept it but partly retrieved— My wife with Mary, Charles’s wife, and Miss Hall went into Boston this afternoon— Except that Miss Hall stopped at her brothers, the Minister of the Church at Dorchester; and I had a succession of visitors from dinner time till dark. Mr Beale came with a Mr Anderson from Texas; who appeared to be labouring with some communication to me, which he did however but very partially reveal.— He said that the People of Texas had very inconsiderately made Slavery a part of their Constitution; and thereby closed their doors against migration from the free States of this Union— They were therefore wholly devoted to the Institution of Slavery. But many of the most intelligent among them think this impolitic and wrong— The natural conclusion from this seemed to be that they wished to make of Texas a free State and to abolish Slavery; but this he did not distinctly avow. He seemed to be desirous of obtaining my opinions, without venturing his own— I said I thought this might be effected by the British Government, and that it appeared to have entered into the views of Mr O’Connell, according to a notice of an intended motion lately given by him in Parliament; but I expected that nothing would come of it; and certainly nothing of that tendency will be done by our Government; but directly the reverse.— Mr E. Price Greenleaf was here; returned some German Books, and borrowed others; and loosened the bands of most of the Apple and Pear-stocks which he had inserted on the 3d. and 10th. of August; almost every one of which he thinks have taken— Mr Francis Jackson brought me a Letter from Mr Ellis Gray Loring, requesting my opinion upon the knotty questions involved in the case of the Spanish ship Amistad recently taken by a vessel of the U.S. engaged on the survey of the Coast, and brought into New-London, having on board about 40 African Slaves, and two Spaniards of the Island of Cuba their owners— The Slaves having been charged with murder and piracy, for taking the ship and putting to death the Captain and one or two other white men— Judge Smith Thomson of the U.S Circuit Court has decided that his Court has no jurisdiction to try the offence of piracy committed on the high Seas in a Spanish vessel; but his opinion is not yet published; and the newspaper account of his decision I think is correct— I desired Mr Jackson to say that I felt some delicacy about answering his Letter until judge Thomsons opinion shall be published and until the final decision of the Government upon the whole case in the mean time—requested him to ask Mr Loring to look up and examine the records of the Circuit Court upon the trial of the Pirates convicted and executed there inand I mentioned to him the refusal of President to deliver up a man charged at Charleston S.C. with Piracy committed on board of a British Vessel— Charles and his wife and Miss Hall spent the Evening here, after the return of the Ladies from Boston— Josiah Adams junr came in the Evening and I read to him the Letter of the Commissioner of Patents H. L. Ellsworth, respecting his Patent for a Bark cutter— He says there is one of them now in full operation, at Gay’s Tan-yard in this town—
24. IV. Tuesday
Sun rose 5:48. Set 5:56 Day 12 hours 8 minutes.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Miss Hall went with him to Boston, and returns home to Medford— Mr Lunt called to enquire for the Cambridge Church record book which I told him Mr Newell had taken with him— Mr Lunt had requested me to furnish him with a hymn to be sung at the centennial anniversary, and I gave him one that I wrote some years since, upon the rapid flight of Time; observing that the reflections in it, were perhaps of too general a nature, for a special occasion, and leaving at his option to use it or not— He said he thought it would do, and that perhaps it would be best to generalize in that part of the Service— Mr James Newcomb was here, and returned the copy of the Resolution of the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund, disapproving the projected lease to Solomon Hayden, which I had left with the Selectmen— And he said that Mr Whittier to whom a similar lease had been promised, for 100 years upon payment of 35 dollars, had manifested some uneasiness at its being denied to him; he having made it already part of his garden; and having thoughts of removing his house itself upon it, to give him the benefit of being upon a more convenient School District— Mr Newcomb asked my advice what to do. I thought the best thing would be to give a lease for 20 years at a rent of 2 dollars and ten cents a year— This proposed example of giving leases for 100 years, without reservation of rent upon the payment of a trifling sum, endangers the whole property; and I propose now to call a meeting of the Supervisors on the third Wednesday of August next, and then to propose as by-laws 1. That there shall be a regular meeting of the board on that day annually. 2. That a minute of all the existing leases shall then be laid before the board by the Secretary, 3 That a Committee of 2 members shall be chosen at every annual meeting to inspect the Library with the Secretary, and to report in writing the condition of the books, and if any of them are missing or have been damaged. 4. That a report of the State of the fund shall be made to the board at every annual meeting by the Treasurer— Other regulations may perhaps be also necessary for the preservation and good management of the property. Mr Newcomb appeared under some solicitude for the elections to the State Government, which are approaching and will be vehemently contested; and particularly for the effect of the license law of April 1838. this and an alteration of the Militia Law by the Legislature of the present year will according to all appearance overthrow the present administration of the State, and throw it into the arms of Van Buren— By the 125th. Section of the 12th. chapter of the revised Statutes, a bounty of 5 dollars a year was allowed to the members of volunteer companies— This bounty was repealed by an act of the 10th. of April last— There was this day a militia muster on the Hancock lot in this town which all the volunteer companies in the County refused to attend, excepting two— The muster was therefore nothing, but it brought together an assemblage of gambling, drunken democrats, as they styled themselves who disgraced the day in fighting and rioting, and forced themselves into the front yard of my house, from which I had no small difficulty in dislodging them— They cleared of however by the dusk of Evening— Charles and his wife were here.
25. IV. Wednesday

An undisturbed day; in the leisure of which I visited my garden, Nursery and Seminary; enlarging the smallest rings of the rows of seedling fruit trees of the seminary. Planted 4 English Oak Acorns in ring 8 of row 6. with the wild strawberry plant which I set out there in June, which has taken root and slowly crept along, nearly across the ring. I enlarged also and dressed Fanny’s border ring, in which there are seedling apples—one puny peach, and a black currant bush. Charles and his wife and children, dined and spent the day with us— Cloudy and a sprinkling of rain towards Sunset.— I answered an invitation from Mr Samuel A. Turner to take a farmer’s dinner with him, and to inspect the place where they want an appropriation from Congress for an improvement— I promised to go, and to be there by or before 10 O’Clock on the 9th. of October this day fortnight.
