And I answered the Letter from Mr George Biddell Airy, the English Astronomer Royal at the Greenwich Observatory; who has furnished me ample information in answer to the enquiries which I proposed to Christopher Hughes last April— Alas! my heart bleeds for poor Hughes—the gay—the sprightly, the witty—the affectionate—the generous— He went from here with a spirit broken down, and the consciousness of a disease in his vitals, which at any day may take him off without an hour of warning—but how little did he foresee that his only and darling Son, his Charles John, in whom he had garnered up his heart, would fall by his own hand within five months after his departure— Oh the Vanity of human life, and human wishes! I have just learnt too the premature, though natural death of John Adams Johnson the son of Alexander B Johnson of New-York, and of the youngest daughter of my long deceased brother Charles—a youth of the brightest promise, barely one year since a graduate with the highest honours of Yale College.— His mother whom I never but once transiently saw was a most excellent and intelligent woman and died scarcely two years since. She had lost one promising son of the same name with this one, in early childhood—and since her death, another, Bryant a fine young man of 19 has followed her to the unseen world, where the wicked cease from troubling, and the weary are at rest.— I this day finished reading William H. Prescotts admirable History of the reign of Ferdinand and Isabella, and began the third volume of Grahame’s History of the United States of America— I lament the want of time to read Prescott’s History at least a second and a third time, for my memory will soon leave me few and faint traces of this single reading. Prescott makes several references to Flechier’s life of Cardinal Ximenes, which I have taken up and transiently examined to see how far his views of men and things accord with those of the American Historian— It will be worthy of a deeper investigation for a comparison of narratives, sentiments, principles and opinions— Flechier was a most excellent man, but politically a bishop subject of Louis the 14th. and in religion a faithful Roman Catholic servant of the Pope.
26. IV. Thursday.
Sun rose 5:50. Set 5:52. Day 12 hours 2 minutes.

I went to Boston this morning in the Carriage, with Louisa C. Smith, and Mrs C. F. Adams’s Nursery Maid Catherine— There had been a very heavy thunder shower in the Night, and the morning was still lowering— I left Louisa at her Sister Foster’s, and was overtaken by a smart clearing up shower, which drove me for shelter, first to the Boylston market Hall, and then to Charles’s Office where I found his tenant Mr Spooner. I called next at Mr Ellis Gray Loring’s Office, and had some conversation with him concerning his Letter to me on the case of the Amistad and her Cargo of Africans— He has not yet obtained the minutes from the records of the U.S. Circuit court of the Piracy trial there when Mr Monroe was President; but will procure them. Mr Francis Jackson came in while I was there— Mr Loring was extremely anxious to obtain my opinion as to the right of the President to deliver up the negroes, upon the demand of the Spanish Minister— Yet the time has not yet come when it would be proper for me to give an opinion for publication— Prudence would forbid my giving an opinion upon it at any time; and if I ever do, it must be with great consideration and self controul— May I walk humbly and uprightly, on this and all other occasion—flinching from no duty—obtruding no officious interposition of opinions, and prepared to meet with firmness whatever obloquy may follow the free expression of my thoughts— At Noon I attended the meeting of the Historical Society: several new members were proposed; among whom J. M. Berrien the President, and Mr Tefft the Secretary of the newly instituted historical Society of Georgia— The Secretary of the Historical Society of Kentuckey was admitted as a corresponding member— I returned the volume of funeral Sermons which I had borrowed, containing that of John Hancock upon Judge Edmund Quincy; and took out the three Manuscripts, which I had promised to procure for Mr Lunt— Dr. Pierce of Brookline, promised to send me extracts from his Church records of all the baptisms of the names of Boylston, and of White connected with them. Mr Lemuel Shattuck requested a copy of the Will of the first Henry Adams, and a sight of the genealogical table of the Adams family made in 1799. by Elijah Adams of Medfield— He also told me, that John Adams the son of the first Henry removed to Concord—and finally to Cambridge so that the names, which I found on the Cambridge Church Records, are all descendants from Henry of Mount Wollaston— President Winthrop’s son Robert C. was proposed as a member of the Society— The old Gentleman invited me to dine with him, but I declined— Isaac P. Davis took me over to the Exhibition of the Horticultural Society, where there was a fine display of flowers—fruits and culinary esculents. I then returned to Mr James H. Fosters, where I saw Mrs Foster and her three daughters. Took up Louisa C. Smith and Catherine, and came home to Quincy to dine— I now learn that all Cars Cows and Oxen were turned last Night into my Orchard ground—broke down and devoured my China Corn, and uprooted all the hills of my Rohan Potatoes— Called at Mr Lunts; but he and Mrs Lunt were gone to Boston— I left the Manuscripts with his daughters— Charles and Abby here.
27. IV. Friday

I observed last Evening’s setting and this morning’s rising Sun, both perfectly clear from Charles’s porch— By the American Almanac the setting was at 5:50—the rising at 5:53—by my watch the setting and rising were both at 5:51:30. forming a perfect equinox of 12 hours.— Charles and I had received a printed circular invitation from Mr B. F. Greenough, proprietor of a new invented chemical oil, for use in the Light-house lamps, and which he wishes to have substituted in the stead of sperm oil, to join a select party of scientific and nautical Gentlemen to embark in the Steamer General Lincoln from the end of Liverpool wharf at four O’Clock this afternoon, to view the light from the Bay and compare its brilliancy with those Lights using Sperm Oil. Charles went to Boston this morning— I after an early dinner went in the Carriage with my wife, Mary’s daughter and Mrs Kirke— Called at Dr Frothingham’s where Charles had dined but was just gone— Then at his Office where I found him with Mr Spooner— We both repaired immediately to the Steamer Genl. Lincoln at Liverpool wharf— It blew a heavy gale from the Southwest; and there was much discussion whether the party should not be postponed till next Monday— The boat however was to take passengers for Hingham and was concluded to go there, and if the Storm should subside at Sunset, then to go out into the Bay— We landed accordingly at Hingham at 6. O’Clock, and marched in procession under the escort of Lieutt. Josiah Sturgis, Commander of the Revenue Cutter with his band of music, and the Crew of his vessel to the Old Colony House— The procession consisted of Alexander H. Everett and myself—Leonard Jarvis and my Son—Mr Treadwell and Winslow Lewis—MrPeabody and Joseph Willard, and half a dozen others unknown to me, and lastly Mr Greenough himself— The Gale instead of subsiding increased in violence as the Sun went down and no one thought of going this Night into the Bay— I sat on the upper deck of the Steamer on the passage to Hingham, noticing Governors and Castle Island—Spectacle Thomson, George’s Pettucks, Long Island—Sheeps and Hangman’s rocks with Nantasket beach and the town of Hull—Quincy—Hough’s Neck, Germantown, and on approaching Hingham the World’s end and sundry other Islands the names of which escaped me— Mr Baker and Jairus Lincoln of Hingham were on board, and many women— Mr Greenough’s party had a comfortable tea and supper and Mr Greenough made his comparative experiments of brilliancy, between the light of Sperm Oil and his chemical composition, in the long Hall of the Hotel—first with large conical reflectors or reverberes—and then with the bare lighted lamps— The chemical compound gave the most brilliant light, but the result of the comparison of the shadows from the naked lights was doubtful, and severely tested by Mr Treadwell— About 9 in the Evening in the party of Mr Greenough with Lieutenant Sturgis, his band and his crew left the Hotel to return in the Steamer to Boston— Charles engaged a four wheeled Chaise with one horse and a man, who took us home to Quincy by land: we had however two or three sprinklings and one very heavy shower of rain, in the midst of which we reached home about half past ten— My wife with her party had returned in the Carriage from Boston, by tea-time— I found a note from Ellis Gray Loring, and a packet of books, with the trial of the Pirates at Boston, in December 1818 and other judicial decisions.
28. IV:45. Saturday

Showery Night, and clearing off day. Charles went in to Boston for his horse and Chaise, and returned home to dine— We have not been able to keep off the making of fires in the dining room— My Thermometer was this morning at 42. and was yesterday morning at 40. I still resist the making of fire in my library, but my fingers are so benumbed that I can no longer write; and the days are so shortened that I lose the long evening hours in idleness. Miss Cutts returned this afternoon from her Eastern expedition, upon which she has been upwards of 3 Months absent.— She came in the Steamer last Night from Portland and the Misses Crowninshield brought her out from Boston— I received some weeks since a Letter from Sidney Peirce dated East Marlborough Chester County Pennsylvania the 9th. of this month, requesting as a favour some thought or sentiment of mine, written with my own hand— The writer represents herself as the daughter of a farmer, having just passed from the fairy dreams of childhood to the sober realities of life, residing beneath the paternal roof, in the South-eastern part of Chester County, Pennsylvania— The hand-writing, the spelling, and composition of the Letter, all indicate a cultivated mind and liberal education; the only deduction from the estimate of which is the fulsome flattery with which her request is urged— But this I suppose emanates from the enthusiasm of Anti-Slavery; not yet refrigerated, as with the great mass of the Abolitionists it has been by the dampers which I have put upon their senseless and overbearing clamour for the immediate, total, uncompensated abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— I have sent to Miss Peirce copies of my Oration upon the life and character of La Fayette, of the fragment Speech of June and July 1838 and of the Jubilee of the Constitution, with the following thought or sentiment of mine written with my own hand on a blank leaf before the Oration on La Fayette.
To Miss Sidney Peirce. Hamorton Post-Office Chester County Pennsylvania

lg.l: Fair Maiden—my Career on Earth is run:
For I have wintered three score years and ten—
This world, to me, is but the Lions den—
My term is closing—thine has just begun.
My thread of life from mingled yarn was spun
The motley web of praise and blame from men
But truth and Freedom have inspir’d my pen
And now from thee a nobler prize have won
Thy voice for me shall fill the trump of Fame,
For thou hast wreath’d a chaplet round my name
More precious than Golconda’s sparkling gem—
More glorious than the Monarch’s diadem
The hero’s laurel or the Martyr’s crown.

div.p: 29. IV:30. Sunday.

This is the centennial day. The third century commences with this day since the formation of the Congregational Church at Mount Wollaston— Mr Lunt preached two historical Sermons on the occasion— In the morning from Deuteronomy 8.11. “Beware that thou forget not the Lord thy God, in not keeping his commandments, and his judgments and his Statutes, which I command thee this day: 12 Lest when thou hast eaten and art full, and hast built goodly houses and dwelt therein;— 14 then thine heart be lifted up, and thou forget the Lord thy God, which brought thee forth out of the land of Egypt, from the house of bondage:— 17. And thou say in thine heart, My power, and the might of mine hand hath gotten me this wealth: 18. But thou shalt remember the Lord thy God; for it is he that giveth thee power to get wealth, that he may establish his covenant, which he sware unto thy fathers, as it is this day.[”] His Doctrine was that the undertaking of the puritans to establish a Christian Commonwealth in the North American wilderness, was a design so vastly beyond their visible means to accomplish, that nothing short of the overpowering energy of religion could have effected it— He illustrated this position by the comparative merit of the sacrifices of Cain and Abel—from the vocation of Abraham— From the Exodus out of Egypt, and finally from the mission of Christ and his apostles— He then gave a historical account of the formation of the Church at Mount Wollaston as connected with the settlement of the town of Braintree—from Morton’s Merry Mount Maypole to the ordination of the Ministers Tompson and Flint. He gave a lucid account of the Sermon of Mr Wheelwright which occasioned the Antinomian controversy, and which he supposed to have been preached here, and paid a handsome tribute to the character of Wheelwright himself— The afternoon text was from John 4:20. “Our fathers worshipped in this Mountain”—and with short biographical notices of the Pastors of the Church Tompson and Flint—Fiske, Marsh, Hancock, Bryant and Wibert—till his venerable colleague formed the link between the past ages and himself he intermingled affecting incidents, glowing sentiments and flashes of admirable eloquence— Mr Peter Whitney made the morning and George Whitney the afternoon prayer— The Communion was administered jointly by the two Pastors after the morning service and Mr Peter Whitney began the afternoon service, with baptizing a child by the name of George Gorham— There was an Anthem sung— Then my Hourglass hymn—and afternoon the 107th. and 102d. Psalms of Sternhold and Hopkins— The last to the tune of Old hundred, read line by line— Isaac P. Davis was here, and dined with us— President Quincy, and his family were also here— The House was well filled. In the Evening I read Parkers 10th. Sermon on Conscience.
30. IV:15. Monday

I had intended to postpone the making of a fire in my chamber at least till the first of October, but this morning I was so chilled in reading before Sunrise that to work myself into a perspiration, I walked to the 6th. mile stone. 17 minutes to a mile 1084 paces, and 1088 between the two milestones and 46 minutes from my gate to it again— After breakfast I had the fire made in my room. There were sprinklings of rain and a raw chilly day, which confined me almost entirely to the house— I answered the application from two literary Societies at the Wesleyan Methodist Universit at Middletown Connecticut to deliver an Oration before them at their Commencement next August—declined—and I received from Lieutt. Josiah Sturgis a sheet of beach-grass paper. My time was much absorbed in examining Bacon’s Abridgement, Valin and Emerigon, upon the principle that pirates of whatever Nation are triable in the Courts of any Country into which they are brought.— I examined also the Act of Congress of 15. May 1820. making further provision for the crime of piracy. Elizabeth C. Adams dined, and spent the day and Evening here— Charles was also here this Evening, but without his wife. I attempted but was unable to read in the Evening.

Day. I rise usually between 4 and 5. O’Clock in the morning, and after visiting my seedling plants, and when the sky is clear going to Charles’s porch to see the Sunrise, and read two hours which brings me to breakfast time before or after which I allow from half to three quarters of an hour to hear my two grand daughters read 5 Chapters in the Bible— Then comes the Mail.—Letters, Newspapers; pamphlets and rob me of at least three hours every day— Then journalizing before or after dinner, an average of at least two hours— Sauntering about my Garden, Nursery Seminary and Orchards to observe very fruitlessly my seedling fruit trees— Desultory reading too in any book of my library which happens to catch my eye wastes enormously my time— Visitors divert my attention, and once or twice a week I am called away for half or the whole day to Boston— Evening twilight comes every day one or two minutes earlier than the last—and the Evening slips away in conversation with my family— I have Letters, often not a little perplexing to answer, but much necessary correspondence falls into irretrievable arrears. With my morning reading of the last six weeks, I have gone through the three Volumes of Prescott’s History of Ferdinand and Isabella and am nearly through the third volume of Grahame’s history of the United States—of which I read 50 pages in two hours— In this distribution of my time, I reserve not one hour a day for the biography of my father, or for any other profitable writing— Accordingly the Summer is gone, and I am where I was when I arrived here on the 2d of May. And in this idle murder of time the American Historical Society at Washington have elected me their President, and called upon me for a discourse to be delivered in the course of the next winter—
